RE: Roberta Vincent MR #380-18-32-2
Dear Dr. Xanthos,
We had the privilege of seeing your patient, Mrs. Roberta Vincent, in the Renal Services Clinic on January 18, 2093. We will not repeat her history as you know it well. Over the past three months Mrs. Vincent has complained of increasing fatigue, occasionally sleeping more than 12 hours per night, forgetfulness and tingling of the fingers and toes. She has maintained a relatively good appetite and denies nausea, vomiting or shortness of breath. An Iothalamate GFR test obtained on December 14, 2092 revealed a glomerular infiltration rate of approximately 10 ml per minute, suggesting profound loss of renal function.
On physical examination today her weight is 99.5 kilograms or 219 pounds. Blood pressure is 150/90, pulse is 80 and regular. The lungs are clear. There is no peripheral edema. Again, there marked cushingoid features. Despite overall weight loss, Mrs. Vincent comments that she has gained facial and abdominal fat as well as facial hair over the past several months.
In summary, Mrs. Vincent appears to be developing early symptoms of uremia. Given her advanced azotemia we believe that she should undergo creation of an arteriovenous fistula so that she may start dialysis within the next several months. We have arranged to recheck her chemistries today. We would also recommend that she undergo repeat work up for her cushingoid features. Although renal failure may alter hormonal balance and may promote occasional androgenic features in woman, this is beyond ordinary.
Thank you once again for allowing us to participate in her care.
Edward Xanthos, M.D. RE: Roberta Vincent MR #380-18-32-2 January 18, 2093 Page #2
Please do not hesitate to contact us if we can be of any further assistance.
Sincerely,
